bestBHT.bht: By responding with kindness to those who have wronged us, we take the most effectual vengeance, heaping figurative coals of fire upon their heads. This divine vengeance stings them with penitence, awakening the memory of their wrong. Through our love and care, even towards enemies, we have the power to promote peace and subdue them, bringing about repentance and shame.

Henry Alford: Clearly not, in their bare literal sense.
Merely to make an enemy ashamed of himself, can hardly be upheld as a motive for action.
I understand the words, ‘For in thus doing, you will be taking the most effectual vengeance:’ as effectual as if you heaped coals of fire on his head.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: That will be the most effectual vengeance—a vengeance under which he will be fain to bend." (ALFORD, HODGE, &c.)
The heaping of 'coals of fire' is in the Old Testament the figurative expression of divine vengeance."
The true sense of these words seems to be, 'That will be the most effectual vengeance—a vengeance under which he will be fain to bend'.
Albert Barnes: If thine enemy is needy in any way, do him good, and supply his needs.
The way to promote 'peace' is to do good even to enemies.
If people would act on the principles of the gospel, the world would soon be at peace.
Marvin Vincent: The memory of the wrong awakened in your enemy by your kindness, shall sting him with penitence.
Perhaps it is better to take it, that kindness is as effectual as coals of fire.
The Arabians call things which cause very acute mental pain, burning coals of the heart and fire in the liver.
John Calvin: But he calls him our enemy, not whom we regard with hatred, but him who entertains enmity towards us.
if he be so savage that nothing can tame him, he shall yet be burnt and tormented by the testimony of his own conscience, on finding himself overwhelmed with our kindness.

such is represented to be kindness to any enemy, to feed him when hungry and to give him drink when thirsty, has commonly such a power over him that he cannot resist its influence, no more than he can withstand the scorching heat of burning coals.
Philip Schaff: Thou wilt prepare for him the glowing shame of penitence.
Simply to make him ashamed is not an exalted motive.
Thou wilt by this kindness most readily subdue him, thus taking the most effectual vengeance.
Archibald T. Robertson: Feed him. Quotation from LXX text of Proverbs 25:21. Present active imperative of verb from ψωμος, a morsel, and so to feed crumbs to babies, then to feed in general."
Thou shalt heap. Future active of old verb σωρευω from σωρος, a heap."
Coals of fire. That is, burning or live coals. Anthrax (our "anthracite") is an old word, only here in N.T. It is a metaphor for keen anguish.
John Gill: ...so far should the saints be from meditating revenge upon their enemies, that they should do good unto them...
By so doing, his conscience would be stung with a sense of former injuries done to his benefactor, and he be filled with shame on account of them, and be brought to repentance...

This advice of showing kindness to enemies, and against private revenge, is very contrary to the dictates of human nature, as corrupted by sin. The Gospel and the grace of God teach us another lesson.
John Wesley: Feed him — With your own hand: if it be needful, even put bread into his mouth.
Heap coals of fire upon his head — That part which is most sensible.
So artists melt the sullen ore of lead, By heaping coals of fire upon its head; In the kind warmth the metal learns to glow, And pure from dross the silver runs below.

bhtAttempts.bht: To truly understand Romans 12:20, we must go beyond its literal meaning and recognize that the intent behind this verse is not to simply make our enemies feel shame. Rather, by responding with kindness to those who have wronged us, we are called to take the most effectual vengeance, a vengeance that will cause our enemies to bend. This act of heaping coals of fire upon their heads serves as a figurative expression of divine vengeance, awakening the memory of their wrong and stinging them with penitence. By extending love and care, even to our enemies, we have the power to subdue them and promote peace.

By extending love and care, even to our enemies, we have the power to subdue them and promote peace. The figurative expression of heaping coals of fire upon their heads signifies a divine vengeance that awakens their memory of the wrong done to us, stinging them with penitence. This act of kindness serves as the most effectual vengeance, bringing about repentance and shame in our enemies. Our response should not be driven by a desire for mere shame, but by the genuine intention to overcome evil with good.
